title: 108_s1633
content: The Act may be cited as the "Identity Theft Notification and Credit Restoration Act of 2003". Congress finds that the privacy and financial security of individuals are increasingly at risk due to widespread collection of personal information. Credit card transactions, real estate records, consumer surveys, credit reports, and Internet websites are all sources of personal information for identity thieves. Identity theft is one of the fastest-growing crimes in the United States, posing a major law enforcement challenge. Criminals use stolen information for fraudulent activities, leading to financial crimes. In 2002, over 160,000 people reported identity theft to the Federal Trade Commission. Identity theft is a growing concern in the United States, with criminals using stolen personal information to commit financial crimes. In 2002, over 160,000 people reported being victims of identity theft, a significant increase from previous years. Victims often face the burden of contacting various law enforcement agencies and credit reporting agencies to address the fraud. It is crucial for the government, financial institutions, and credit reporting agencies to work together to protect consumer information and assist victims of identity theft. Service providers, credit reporting agencies, and the private sector have a shared responsibility to protect consumers' sensitive personal information from identity theft. Improving customer notification, implementing fraud alerts, providing greater access to credit reports, and establishing financial identity theft prevention measures can better protect consumers. Subtitle B of title V of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act is amended to include a new section 526, which requires timely notification to customers of unauthorized access to personal information. The new section 526 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act defines a breach as the unauthorized acquisition of personal information compromising security, confidentiality, or integrity. Personal information includes the first name or initial and last name of a customer, along with sensitive data like social security numbers or driver's license numbers. The new section 526 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act defines a breach as the unauthorized acquisition of personal information compromising security, confidentiality, or integrity. This includes the customer's name, social security number, driver's license number, credit card information, and other sensitive data. Financial institutions must promptly notify affected customers and consumer reporting agencies in case of a breach. Financial institutions must promptly notify affected customers, consumer reporting agencies, and law enforcement agencies in case of a breach. Any entity holding personal information for a financial institution must also notify them of any breaches. Notification must be timely. Financial institutions must be promptly notified of any breaches of customer information by entities holding such data. Notification should be made without delay, taking into account law enforcement needs and measures to assess the breach's extent and restore information security. Delays in notification for law enforcement purposes are allowed if it would impede a criminal investigation. Notification required by this section may be delayed for law enforcement purposes if it would impede a criminal investigation. The form of notice can be provided in writing, electronically, or in other forms determined by the Federal Trade Commission based on the number of affected customers or the cost of notifications. The Federal Trade Commission may allow notification through e-mail, website posting, or media for breaches affecting a large number of customers or with insufficient contact information. The Federal Trade Commission may allow notification through e-mail, website posting, or media for breaches affecting a large number of customers or with insufficient contact information. Notifications to customers must include a statement that credit reporting agencies have been informed of the breach. Each notification to a customer under subsection (b) must include a statement that credit reporting agencies have been notified of the breach, and the customer's credit report will have a fraud alert. Additional information may be included as determined by the Federal Trade Commission. Financial institutions are considered compliant if they have a comprehensive information security program. The Federal Trade Commission requires financial institutions to have a comprehensive information security program and notify customers and consumer reporting agencies of any breaches. Customers can seek damages for violations of this section through civil action. Civil penalties for violations of this section include the ability for customers to seek damages and injunctions against financial institutions. The rights and remedies under this section are additional to those available under other laws. Compliance with this section does not constitute a violation of other laws regarding the disclosure of financial information. The financial institution is not in violation of laws prohibiting the disclosure of financial information to third parties, except as specifically provided in this section. There is no new recordkeeping obligation imposed on financial institutions under this section. SEC. 4. INCLUSION OF FRAUD ALERTS IN CONSUMER CREDIT REPORTS. Section 605 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include a definition of fraud alerts, which notify users of a consumer's credit report that their identity may have been used fraudulently. The consumer must authorize any credit issuance or extension after providing evidence of their true identity. The Fair Credit Reporting Act now requires consumers to provide evidence of their true identity before authorizing any credit issuance. Consumer reporting agencies must include a fraud alert in the consumer's file promptly upon notification by a financial institution or upon the consumer's request. The Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act requires consumer reporting agencies to include a fraud alert in a consumer's file upon request, with evidence of identity theft provided. Agencies must also inform any entity accessing the consumer's credit information about the presence of a fraud alert. Consumer reporting agencies must inform anyone requesting consumer credit information about the presence of a fraud alert in the consumer's file. The Federal Trade Commission will establish regulations for the duration of fraud alerts and procedures for their removal. Failure to notify users of a fraud alert in a credit report is a violation. Consumer reporting agencies must notify users of a fraud alert in a consumer credit report. Failure to do so is a violation of the section, as is issuing credit to someone other than the consumer without following fraud alert procedures. Adverse actions based solely on a fraud alert are also prohibited. Access to credit reports and scores is addressed in Section 5. Section 612(c) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to provide consumers with no-cost access to credit reports and scores. Consumers can request disclosures once a year and every 3 months if a fraud alert is in place. Credit reporting agencies can charge a fee for disclosures related to fraud alerts. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to provide consumers with free access to credit reports and scores. Credit reporting agencies can charge a fee for disclosures related to fraud alerts. The Federal Trade Commission must issue final regulations within 180 days of this Act's enactment, in consultation with relevant financial regulatory agencies, to implement the amendments.
